Award.AwardTitle: BioTiER (Biological Training in Education and Research) Scholars Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goals of the BioTiER (Biological Training in Education and Research) Scholars S-STEM Program project at Cal Poly Pomona are to (1) increase recruitment and retention of underrepresented minority and financially disadvantaged students pursuing advanced degrees in the biological sciences, (2) increase graduation rates and decrease time to degree, and (3) offer career development opportunities so students adapt and excel once in the STEM workforce.

Intellectual Merit derives from the sector-specific training program along three career tracks offered in (1) STEM industries including biotechnology, environmental/green technology, biomedical engineering & pharmaceutical, (2) academia & faculty training, and (3) pursuit of other STEM fields requiring advanced degrees. This project is poised to create an educational network comprised of community colleges, companies in the STEM industries, and research universities with the Biological Sciences Department at Cal Poly Pomona serving as the central point of training and education.

Broader Impacts are realized by providing a better educated workforce entering the U.S. and California life sciences and engineering industries where demand for skilled workers with degrees beyond the Bachelor's level is growing. Further, this project provides high-quality life science educators available to institutions of higher learning, in particular community colleges. The activities created for the program are planned to become part of an already existing infrastructure, so that the novel benefits of the program will continue even after the end of the grant period. Plans are in place to share project findings, instructional materials, and best practices models with local and national entities with a similar purpose.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Young, developing scientists preparing for today's demanding work environment need both rigorous scientific training and sector-specific cultivation. The BioTiER (Biological Training in Education and Research) Scholars Programwas designed to address these needs. The BioTiERprogram offered programming along 3 career-training tracks for those pursuing careers in (1) STEM industries including biotechnology, environmental/green technology, biomedical engineering or pharmaceutical industries, (2) academia as a faculty member in a physical or life science department at the community college level, and (3) STEM fields that require the doctoral degree (Ph.D). The objectives of the BioTiER Scholars Programwere the following:

 

Objective 1: Increase the number of financially disadvantaged students pursuing higher degrees in the biological sciences, with particular attention on those from under-represented minorities

Objective 2: Integrate sector specific career skills into graduate training in order to better prepare the scholars to exceed workplace demands in the various life & physical science industries that fuel the California and US economy

Objective 3: Maximize retention of students within the graduate program, while decreasing their time to degree

 

 

5-Year Summary

 

Objective 1:

Before establishment of the BioTiER program, the Biological Sciences Department had maintained a 15% Latino/Hispanic student population. Throughout the program’s 5-year period, BioTiER supported an overall cohort that was 45% Latino/Hispanic. Therefore, the BioTiER cohorts have aided the Biological Sciences Department to increase its underrepresented minority enrollment.

 

Objective 2: 

BioTiER created an educational network comprised of community colleges, companies in the STEM industries, and R01 research universities, with the Biological Sciences Department at Cal Poly Pomona as the central point of training and education. These partners allowed BioTiER scholars to have site visits, during which scholars interviewed lab members or faculty, learn about the PhD programs at each institution and gained perspective as to the expectations and program specifics in the graduate programs, companies or JCs. The partner institutions who received our scholars included the following. 

 

R01 research labs that partnered with BioTiER to provide CPP student site visits.

  • California Institute of Technology 
  • Cedars-Sinai
  • City of Hope Cancer Center
  • FDA/Pacific Regional Laboratory Southwest, Irvine, CA
  • Salk Institute
  • University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA)
  • UC Irvine
  • UC San Diego 
  • UC Riverside 
  • UC Davis
  • University of Kansas
  • University of Southern California
  • Western University of Health Science

 

The Biology or Life Science Departments at the following Community Colleges partnered with BioTiER to provide CPP student site visits.

 

  • Chaffey Community College 
  • Citrus Community College
  • College of the Canyons
  • Glendale Community College
  • Mt. San Antonio College (Mt. SAC)
  • Mt. San Jacinto Community College
  • Norco Community College
  • Pasadena City College
  • Rio Hondo Community College
  • Riverside Community College
  • Victor Valley College

 

 

The following industry companies partnered with BioTiER to provide CPP student site visits.

  • BioMedix 
  • Gilead Sciences, Inc
  • Helica Biosystems, Inc. 
  • Med-Pharmex Inc. 
  • Prolacta 
  • Virun Inc. 

 

 

Training and professional development

 

The Biological Sciences Department offers “Bio 691 Biological Training in Education & Research” each quarter to support the BioTiER program. Within the course, the program offers workshops on PhD preparation, industry and on pedagogy, as well as career projects. 

 

PhD preparation workshops include the following.

  • Ethics in Science
  • Quantitative Reasoning GRE
  • Verbal Reasoning GRE
  • Analytical Writing GRE
  • Personal Statement workshop

 

Coordinated Industry workshops. 

  • Overview of the Life Science Industry
  • How to Start Your Own Company workshop
  • How to prepare a Standard Operating Procedure 
  • Drug Safety and Quality workshop
  • How drugs Are Approved workshop and how to prepare a Standard Operating Procedure

 

Coordinated Pedagogy workshops.

  • Using How People Learn to develop Learning Objectives
  • Aligning Assessments with Learning Objectives
  • Using Active Learning Approached within a Lecture
  • Incorporating the Practices of Science into Content Activities
  • Showcase of Approaches to Active Learning

 

 

Objective 3:

Regarding student retention, of the 50 unduplicated BioTiER scholars, only 3 did not continue in the Master’s program. That is a retention rate of 94%. Of those 3 who did not continue, two left to attend PhD programs before completing the Masters. That is a current success rate of 98%. While half of the BioTiER scholars are still working towards their Master’s thesis, 11 have been admitted to PhD programs, 10 are in industry, 4 are instructors and 1 was admitted to medical school. The BioTiER program is being institutionalized by the Biological Sciences Department and will be a required program for all incoming Masters students.

 

The infrastructure and tools built by the program will continue to result in a positive impact on the number of well-trained professionals entering the U.S. and California STEM industries. It will also have a direct impact on the number of high quality life science educators available to institutions of higher learning, at both community colleges and at California State Universities. The Biological Sciences Department will continue to partner with the BioTiER partner institutions as we expand our efforts to support graduate scholars heading into industry, faculty positions and PhD programs.
